Fredy Suyapa, 33, is married and has four children who are 2, 6, 12 and 14 years old; three of them are in school.  Her husband works at a gas station in the city.  They live in a suburban zone in San Pedro Sula.

She is very hardworking.  She has a stationary stand in the market where she sells merchandise like women’s underwear, children’s clothes like diapers, shirts and blouses.  She works 8 hours per day, every day.

She opened the business a year ago aiming at generating more income for her household and to cover all expenses.  This is her first loan and it will be used to buy women’s and children’s underwear so that she can increase her inventory and sell more.  Her plan is to expand the business more.

loans.use: to buy women's underwear and children's clothes.

loans.name: Maota

texts.en:
Maota is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Taga. She is married and has 6 school-aged children.  To make a living, Maota raises cattle for sale.  Maota has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1120 WST a month.

In 2010, Maota joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Maota has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1500 WST from SPBD, used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell, and is now requesting a new loan of 1950 WST which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. The loan will be the third taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Maota plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Samon's Group

texts.en:
Samon is 42 years old, widowed and has five children, three of whom are working in Malaysia to complement the family’s income. She has struggled to earn a living in a rural area of the Ratanak Mondul district by planting maize as a primary income for more than 10 years. Sometimes, she works for others at a maize plantation to raise additional income. 

Samon leads a group of three female members, and is applying for the first loan with VisionFund. She will use this loan to pay for labourers in harvesting her maize. This loan will enable her to harvest all her maize crops to be ready for sale. She also hopes to earn more income to make a better living so as to live all together with her children.

loans.use: to pay for labourers in harvesting her maize

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 6 children. Romeo has a shop that buys and sells bananas and corn grains. He has had this business for 4 years. He requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to buy bananas and corn grains to sell. Romeo has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. 

In the future, Romeo hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and corn grains to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: maintain his moto-taxi.

loans.name: Shifaa

texts.en: Shifaa, aged 29, with two daughters at home (aged five and six), qualified as a dentist at El Quds University and has completed her apprenticeship and two years further work. She now wishes to set up an independent practice in Sur Baher in south Jerusalem, not far from her home in Sharfat, where she lives with her husband, an electrical engineer. There are currently two dental practices in Sur Baher but neither employs any female dentist. As the community in this area is traditional, it is likely that many women would prefer to be treated by a female dentist. She also has been commended for her gentle touch, which is important especially with small children; so she has acquired much experience working with young patients. Therefore, she intends to specialise in the treatment of young children. Finally, she recognises a need in the community to provide dental services at home for elderly housebound patients. She has received business training from MATI (a local training organisation). So, she now plans to acquire the equipment to set up her dental practice. She has negotiated a deal with an organisation that specialises in providing such equipment – the overall cost would be NIS 64,000 but she needs a downpayment of NIS 27,000. She seeks to borrow NIS 18,000 and use her savings for the remaining balance.

loans.use: to acquire the equipment to set up her dental practice

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda used her previous loan to improve her inventory. She requested another loan for 16,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase grocery items for her sari-sari store. This loan will help sustain the family's needs. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and educate her children.

Yolanda meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Peace Shalom Group

texts.en:
Margaret lives in Teshi,married with a daughter who is a student in her elementary level of education and is a business woman. She became involved in business activities a few year ago with her own working capital and she does her best with it. She is very interested in doing business. She has a small store and hopes to open a bigger store, but her capital is not enough.

She is requesting a loan from ID-Ghana to improve her business. She will use this loan to buy additional items to keep in her store, including cooking oils, detergents, candles, shampoo, eggs, salt, biscuits, candies, soft drinks and other things to sell. She is taking this loan because she also wants to improve her management of her business in the future.

She is the group leader of peace shalom group with other two counterparts who sells charcoal.

With all diligent and loyalty they promise to hold each other responsible for the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy additional items to keep in her store,

loans.name: Claudia Verónica

texts.en:
Claudia lives with her husband and 4-yeard old son in Monclova, Coahuila. About a year ago her family was faced with many challenges, especially because her husband could not find a job. Their family in the United States came through for them with clothing and toys to sell to be able to earn some money to cover their necessities. This was the beginning of their small business, and now they require a loan of $200 to purchase more inventory through their family in the U.S. The loan will be repaid within 3 to 6 months.

Help Claudia keep up her business and secure a better future for her baby boy. Your help is very much appreciated.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

En la localidad de Monclova, Coahuila, vive Claudia, con su esposo e hijo de 4 años de edad. Hace un año su familia enfrentó severos problemas, pues su marido no encontraba empleo, frente a ésta situación sus familiares, quienes son residentes en Estados Unidos, comenzaron a enviarle ropa y juguetes para que los pudiera vender y así poder cubrir las necesidades que tenía. Es así como comenzó su propio negocio, y ahora ella requiere de un préstamo de $200 dólares para poder seguir comprando mercancía por medio de sus familiares, mismo que piensa cubrir en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses.

Apoya a Claudia para que pueda seguir ayudando a su esposo y asegurar un mejor futuro para su pequeño, en tus manos ésta el poder hacerlo, sólo hace falta que te decidas, ella te lo agradece.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Néstor

texts.en:
Don Néstor has had a woodvarnishing shop for the past 20 years and he specializes in making coffins. His experience began at the age of 14 when working with his brothers who taught him the trade, which they had made their source of income. He opened his shop with the help of his brother in law who lent him a small start-up capital, which allowed him to produce the coffins and offer them to clients in the city.

Don Néstor will buy: wood, nails, fabric, lacquer, and paint. He hopes to sell more of his product outside of the city since he has been recommended to funeral homes in other cities like Esmeraldas, Santo Domingo, Cuenca, and Milagro. With his loan he will invest more in raw materials and cover orders from Quito, pleasing his customers and increasing sales which will generate more income.

Néstor is a 41 year old married father of three girls. His wife helps him to upholster the coffins. The business is his sole source of income which has allowed him to acquire land where he’s building his house and workshop bit by bit. He hopes the business will keep growing and generate work, thus obtaining not only personal/ familial wellbeing, but also that of others.

Translated from Spanish by Ari Þór Vilhjálmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Don Néstor tiene taller de ebanistería desde hace 20 años y su negocio especifico es la producción de cofres mortuorios. Su experiencia viene desde la edad de 14 años trabajando con sus hermanos que le enseñaron el oficio tomando este como su fuente de ingreso. Se inicio con su pequeño taller con la ayuda de su cuñado que le financio un pequeño capital en esa época en sucres que le permitió producir los cofres y ofrecerlos a sus clientes en la ciudad

Don Néstor comprara: madera, clavos, telas, laca, pintura. El aspira vender más sus productos fuera de la ciudad ya que como tiene buen acabado lo han recomendado a otras funerarias fuera de la ciudad como Esmeraldas, Santo Domingo, Cuenca, Milagro. Con el préstamo invertirá mas en materia prima y cubrir pedido de Quito satisfaciendo de esta manera a sus clientes e incrementar mas sus ventas que le generaran mayores ingresos.

Néstor tiene 41 años es casado padre de tres niñas, esposa le ayuda en el negocio con la Tapizada de los cofres mortuorios. El negocio es su única fuente de ingresos que le ha Permitido obtener su terreno donde poco a poco esta construyendo su vivienda y taller. Aspira seguir creciendo y generar fuente de trabajo y así no solo tener bienestar personal-familiar, sino también a otras personas.

loans.use: Buy raw material

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
"I've had my business for 1 year, selling tacos and barbecue. It's going well for me, since I'm on a street where there are many points of sale in garages, but I would like to buy a truck that will be sold to me for a cheap price, since it's run down. It will work very well for me to take it to another point in the city and to increase my sales that way." I am requesting R1200 to purchase a truck.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

“Tengo mi negocio desde hace 1 año, vendo tacos de barbacoa y me va bien ya que estoy en una calle en donde se ponen muchos puestos en venta de garaje; pero gustaría comprar un camión que me venden barato debido a que esta descompuesto pero a mi me serviría mucho para ponerlo en otro punto de la ciudad y así aumentar mis ventas”. Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para compra un camión.

loans.use: Buy a truck to open another taco business

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario T. Veron is a very hard worker. Starting 15 years ago, he began his micro enterprise creating bricks. Mario is 49-years old, married, and father of four children aged 24, 22, 19, and 16. With the help of his children, he has been able to successful run his business. Over 80 percent of the people in the city of Itá work in this field. Actually, it is the most profitable business to start because in every 15 days he can make up to US$400, which is higher than most incomes. It takes him 15 days to make a load of bricks ready to sell usually about 25,000 bricks. Mario works from 7 am to 11 am and then from 1 pm to 5 pm, using as much daylight as possible.

Mario has 5 clients that buy from him regularly. Mario works in a field area not far from his house. His clients bring their own trucks to load the bricks every month usually to transport to Asuncion, the capital. The bricks are used for building houses in Asuncion, the most common material used in Paraguay to build houses.

In addition, Mario owns 3 horses that help him mix the different ingredients together before they mold it and let it dry. He has two stations that he has set up for mixing. With the loan, Mario will buy wood chips used as part of the mixture and lumber used for firing the bricks.

loans.use: Purchase wood chips and lumber.

loans.name: Virgínia Jaime

texts.pt:
Virgínia Jaime M. does accountanting and sales for the Mahungueles, she sells plastic kitchenware and chickens. Vitória Maria Jango is the other member of the group, she sells cooking oil. They both live in the neighborhood of Magoanine in Maputo. The Magungueles joined the FDM fund in 2005, they are in the 7th cycle of the credit program and ask for a loan of 11.840MT.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga Kiva Volunteer.

Virgínia Jaime M. é tesoureira do grupo M.. A outra membro do grupo é a senhora Vitória Maria Jango. A primeira vende loiça plástica e faz criação de frangos e a segunda vende óleo alimentar. Ambas vivem no bairro Magoanine em Maputo. o Grupo entrou para o programa em Outubro de 2005 e vai para o 7º ciclo e vai tomar um empréstimo total de 11.840MT.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Hasadia

texts.en:
Hasadia has a shop and sells all types of items. She is married and has five children ages 10, 14, 17, 23 and 25. Her husband is a security guard. Hasadia works very hard to improve her family's living standard. She is asking for a loan of USD 275 to buy products for her business. She proposing to repay the loan in 12 months She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback" arrangement.

loans.use: Buying cooler box and plastic chairs

loans.name: Monassa

texts.en:
Monassa K. sells various fruits and vegetables. She is 36 years old and lives with her cohabitant and their 3 children in Sassandra, a rural city on the south-west coast of Cote d'Ivoire.

Monassa purchases goods in bulk from different villages in the Sassandra region and she then retails them at the Sassandra market in Abidjan. She is dynamic and well organized. She has been in the AE&I microcredit program since 2005 and has performed very well.

loans.use: to purchase goods in bulk for re-sale at her fruit and vegetable stand

loans.name: Zinyet

texts.en:
Zinyet A. lives in Beylagan, a small city in Azerbaijan. She is 43 years old, married and has three children.

She has a clothing sale business in the Beylagan city bazaar. Her husband (pictured), helps her run the business. She started her business ten years ago. She's requesting a loan of $800 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Sokheang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokheang was married in 2000 and has two daughters who are studying in a village school. She has been weaving and raising pigs at home for 8 years. For nearly 15 years, her husband has been selling baby pigs. He usually drives a motorbike to travel from place to place to buy and sell pigs.

Sokheang is requesting a loan for $1000 from MAXIMA to purchase more pigs to resell. This is the fourth loan that Sokheang has requested. Sokheang and her husband hope that this business will be able to support the family and provide enough income so their two daughters can continue their studying and attend high school in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to resell

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es:
Gloria is 51 years old and married. Her husband works as a cheese merchant los Mercados de la Capital - the Ivan Montenegro markets in the capital city. They have 3 children, who are grown and live with them to support them financially. This family lives in the 14th district of Febrero. It has been 10 years that Gloria has had a small store in her humble home to support her husband and to have other means of income to support her children's education and other familial costs. The business has a small inventory but is well stocked with nutritious products that are consumed daily by families all around. At the moment, Gloria seeks a loan to restock her small store since she sells a large portion of goods to her customers on credit, which causes financial strains on her until she is able to collect the money on due dates. She does not have enough inventory for her customers that visit her daily.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

La señora Gloria tiene 51 años de edad, es casada y su esposo trabaja como comerciante de queso en uno de los Mercados de la Capital, de nombre Ivan Montenegro. Procrearon 3 hijos, los cuales son mayores de edad, viven con ellos y le ayudan económicamente en los gastos de la casa, esta familia habita en barrio 14 de Febrero. Hace 10 años, la señora con el proposito de apoyar a su esposo y tener otro ingreso que les permitiera darles la mejor educación posible a sus hijos, montó una pequeña pulpería en su humilde vivienda con el objetivo de obtener mayores ingresos con los cuales pudiera hacer frente a todos los gastos familiares. El negocio posee un inventario pequeño pero se encuentra bien surtido de productos alimenticios tiene de todo un poco de lo que a diario consumen las familias. En este momento la señora solicita un préstamo para abastecer de productos la pulpería, ya que como a diario vende grandes cantidades de productos al crédito y esto a veces la limita económicamente siendo hasta en las fechas de pagos que recoge dinero, en existencia no cuenta con suficiente inventario para cubrir la necesidad de los clientes que la visitan diariamente.

loans.use: To buy meat, vegetables, milk, eggs, etc to stock up her small store

loans.name: Badrul

texts.id:
Badrul M. (25 years old) lives in a rented room in Jl.Bedahulu with her wife and their 2 children. To support the family, Badrul should work hard. Everyday, he starts to walk and collect trash from 05.00 a.m., has a little rest at noon, and continues his activity until afternoon. His wife usually helps him to sort the trash and classify them. The trash is usually sold within 3 days.

Badrul wishes to earn the loan, so that he would be able to purchase second-hands goods from his neighbors and resell them.

Translated from Indonesian by Hestyana, Kiva Volunteer.

Badrul M. (25 th) tinggal di Jl.Bedahulu dengan menyewa sebuah kamar bersama istri dan 2 (dua) orang anaknya. Keadaan keluarganya sehat, tetapi karena harus membiayai anaknya yang masih sekolah, setiap hari Badrul harus bekerja keras mulai pukul 05.00 pagi dengan berkeliling mencari barang-barang bekas hingga tengah hari dan kembali melakukan aktifitas yang sama pada sore harinya. Biasanya dia dibantu oleh istrinya, tetapi istrinya hanya membantu menyortir atau memilah barang yang masih bagus dan yang tidak. Hasil yang didapat biasanya sudah dijual dalam jangka waktu 3 (tiga) hari. Badrul berharap dengan bantuan pinjaman kali ini dia bisa membeli barang-barang bekas milik warga sekitarnya dan kemudian menjualnya kembali.

loans.use: As the capital to purchase second-hands goods to be rsold

loans.name: Arleth Azenete

texts.es:
Arleth is separated from her husband and has three children. She began her business because she wanted to become independent and take advantage of savings to start her own business. In addition, she wanted to pay her housing bills. She began her business selling tacos a year ago with a grill and four tables.

Arleth needs a loan of US $1,200, which she will repay in 6 months, in order to purchase ingredients and, therefore, increase her sales by offering a greater variety on the menu of her establishment.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Arleth esta separada de su marido y tiene 3 hijos. Inició el negocio porque se quería independizar y aprovechar un ahorro que tenia para iniciar su propio negocio, además que debía solventar los gastos de su casa. Comenzó su negocio de venta de tacos hace un año con una parrilla y cuatro mesas.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $ 1200 que pagara en 6 meses para comprara insumos y asi incrementar sus ventas ofreciendo mayor variedad en el menú que ofrece en su establecimiento

loans.use: Purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Kutfi

texts.ru:
Kutfi G. finished her first loan and with happiness would like to continue being a MicroInvest client. She is grateful to KIVA investors for their support and financing. Kutfi travels by herself to Bishkek to purchase products. In the future she would like to expand her business and to open another sales location where her son will work as a salesman.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Кутфи Гадойбоева закончила свой первый займ и с радостью хочет продолжить кредитоваться в Микроинвесте.Она благодарна инвесторам за поддержку и финансирование.Кутфи сама ездит в Бишкек за товаром, в дальнейшем она хочет расширить свой бизнес и открыть ещё одну точку продажи , а продавцом взять к себе своего сына.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Thi Phuong

texts.vi:
Mrs. Luu Thi Phuong, 48 years old, has been a member of the TYM Fund since 2000. After 7 years of borrowing to invest in breeding chickens and pigs, her family's economy has improved. She has 4 children, 2 are working overseas as factory workers, while the other 2 also have stable jobs. Beside the profits from breeding chickens and pigs, there is also her husband's monthly income of about 1,5000,000VND as he works as a construction worker. This time round, she would like to borrow 6,000,000VND (375USD) to purchase cattle to raise. Her average monthly income is 2,500,000VND (about 101USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lưu Thị Phượng năm nay 48 tuổi. Chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000.Qua 7 năm sử dụng vốn chủ yếu vào dự án chăn nuôi lợn, gà có hiệu quả, hiện nay kinh tế gia đình chị đã ổn định hơn. Gia đình chị có 4 người con trong đó có 2 con đã đi lao động xuất khẩu, hai con hiện đang sống cùng anh chị cũng đã có công việc làm ổn định. Ngoài thu nhập từ dự án chăn nuôi, hiện nay gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu khoảng 1.500.000đ /tháng từ công việc thợ xây của chồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 6.000.000 đ để mua trâu về nuôi phục vụ sản xuất.Thu nhập bình quân 2.500.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Raising cows

loans.name: Agnes

texts.fr:
Ms. Agnès Berthé is 36 years old and lives with her three children (one boy and two girls), her husband, and parents in a large, traditional, extended family in Kôkô district of Koutiala Prefecture (third economic region of Mali).

From a tender age, she started earning income in all kinds of ways but decided in the end to specialize in the transformation of “néré en Sounbala” seeds (a natural condiment with many virtues). She learned how to do this very early on from her mom (like most women of her ethnic group: the Minianka). She has been doing this work in her home for fifteen years. To obtain the supplementary financial resources, she decided to turn to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which she is on her first individual loan.

She gets her basic supplies in the villages surrounding Koutiala on market days. With this loan, she intends to buy 30 sacks of néré seeds of different grades that she will have taken to Koutiala. These seeds are pounded, boiled, and crushed and then transformed into rounded forms or into a powder. Next, these Sounbala are put into a container for sale in bulk in Koutiala with enterprises at the marketplace or in the home. A portion of the production is dispatched to Sikasso and to Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) and is sold on credit, payable monthly, and sometimes by cash, to customers essentially made up of women and retailers.

With this new loan, she intends to realize a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that she intends to use to cover the loan interest and to help with family expenses, the bulk of which falls upon her shoulders.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, a Kiva volunteer

Madame Agnès Berthé est âgée de 36 ans et vit avec ses 3 enfants (1 garçon et 2 filles) son mari et des parents dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier Kôkô de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région économique du Mali)

Depuis sa tendre enfance elle commence les activités génératrices de revenus de toutes sortes, mais décide finalement de se spécialiser dans la transformation des graines de néré en Sounbala (un condiment alimentaire naturel aux vertus multiples) qu’elle apprena très tôt auprès de sa maman (comme la plupart des femmes de son ethnie : les Minianka). Elle exerce cette activité à son domicile il y a de cela 15 ans. Pour obtenir des ressources financières complémentaires elle décida de faire recourt à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.

Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières dans les villages environnants de Koutiala pendant les jours de foire. Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter 30 sacs de graine de néré de différentes qualités qu’elle fera acheminer à Koutiala. Ces graines sont pilées, bouillies avant d’être écrasées et transformées en boules de différentes formes ou en poudre. Ensuite ces Sounbala sont mises dans des récipients pour la vente en vrac à Koutiala au niveau des entreprises au marché ou à la maison. Une partie de la production est expédiée à Sikasso et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et vendue à crédit payable mensuellement, quelque fois au comptant, à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes et de revendeurs.

Avec ce nouveau prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qu’elle compte utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt et participer aux dépense de la famille dont l'essentielle repose sur elle.

loans.use: To by néré seeds

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Koffi M. est âgé de 45 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. Il tient une boutique d’alimentation générale à Kpalimé, une ville située à environ 120 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il désire augmenter la capacité de son commerce en achetant des cartons de laits, de sucres, des sacs de riz et autres boîtes de conserves. Ses ventes lui permettront de rembourser le crédit et de dégager des profits pour la survie de sa famille
texts.en:
Koffi M., 45, is married and the father of 4 children. He tends a little general store in Kpalimé, a town that is located about 120 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He wants to bolster his business by buying cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice, and tinned goods. His sales will allow him to reimburse the loan and have profit to support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying cases of milk, sugar, sacks of rice, and tinned goods

loans.name: Meipo

texts.en: Meipo I., 27, is married with 4 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taxi business. She works 5 days a week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Meipo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to fund repairing seats, new parking lights, tires and a front rear window. Her husband is lending his full support to his wife in operating her business.

loans.use: Repairing seats and purchasing new parking lights, tires and a front rear window

loans.name: Futuro Presente Group

texts.es: hola nosotras somos el grupo Futuro Presente todas somos mujeres nos llevamos muy bien, somos muy luchadoras y tenemos muchas ganas de superanos, somos vecinas cercanas y tenemos mucha experiencia en lo que hacemos, nuestro grupo se integra de esta manera:nDoris F.: soy la coordinadora del grupo me dedico a la venta de ropa, compro fardos de ropa americana, tengo 4 años de dedicarme a esta actividad, en estos momentos necesito comprar varios fardos de ropa ya que esta temporada es muy buena y las ventas son excelentes por la navidad.nMaria M.: ella es una señora de la tercera edad, ella se dedica a la produccion y venta de tortillas, en estos momentos ella necesita comprar frutas de la temporada como ser uvas, manzanas y bananos ya que son buena venta para estos ultimos meses del año,.nFrancisca R.: ella es una señora que vende tortillas desde hace varios años, ella necesita el credito para arreglar su lugar de trabajo, remodelar el fogon y las planchas donde prepara las tortillas.ntodas necesitamos un credito para sacar adelante nuestros negocios.
texts.en:
Hello! We are members of the Futuro Presente (Present Future) group. We are all women and get along well. We are hard-working women with the desire for self-improvement. We are neighbors and have many years of experience doing what we do. Our group is comprised of the following members: Doris F.: “I am the coordinator of the group. I sell clothing, purchasing bundles of American apparel. I have been in the business for 4 years. At this time, I need to purchase several bundles of clothing because sales are excellent during the Christmas season.” Maria M. is an elderly woman who makes and sells tortillas. At this time, she needs to purchase seasonal fruits like grapes, apples and bananas because they are good products to sell during the last months of the year. Francisca R. is a woman who has been selling tortillas for several years. She needs the loan in order to repair her workplace, and remodel the wood burning stove and griddles on which she prepares the tortillas. “We all need a loan in order to help move our businesses forward.”

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing, corn and fruit

loans.name: Mikocheni A Group

texts.en:
John N., age 55, is married with 6 children. He owns a hardware shop that he started in 1999. He works daily from 8:00 AM to 8:30 PM daily. He is able to earn a monthly profit of $122. 

John has previously taken 2 loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, which he has repaid successfully. He is now requesting a new loan to improve his wife's beauty salon. He is hoping to paint it for starters!

John is part of subgroup A of the Mikocheni Group. His subgroup consists of 8 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, John is the only man.

loans.use: To increase the quality of his wife's beauty salon

loans.name: Tony

texts.en:
Tony P. is a 30 year old businessman who is married, with three children. For four years, he has owned a boutique shop that sells men suits, shirts, trousers, shoes, belts and caps. Tony says he purchases his stock from major wholesale outlets in Accra and sometimes travels to China. He wants to have more working capital to enable him to purchase in bulk quantities during his trips. With the loan, he believes he would be more resourced to purchase good quality stock to satisfy his customers. He hopes that he can increase his profit margin substantially to enable him support his family, especially the education of his kids. 

Tony is in a loan group called Shadrack Trust Bank. The members in the group guarantee for one another as collateral to access loans and to provide assistance to one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To expand clothing business

loans.name: Chandra Bedi

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandra Bedi M. is a 41-year-old woman and she lives in Thecho. She lives in a single family with her husband, a daughter, and a son. Her husband, Mr. Asta M., works as a laborer in housing construction. The income of her family is so low that their life is miserable. They hardly can fulfill their needs. She can't provide good education for her children.

Mrs. M. is a farmer. She has her own land. She grows different vegetables like cauliflower and green vegetables. She sells vegetables in a local market in the morning and in the evening every day. With her first loan from Kiva she was able to purchase the necessary fertilizer and seeds for this year's monsoon growing season. Now she seeks a loan of Rs15, 000 to buy fertilizer and seeds for her work.

Her daughter is now studying in grade 7 and her son is in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is 43 years old and married to Martino, who operates a jeep to and from their village at Alibagu to Centro Ilagan, Isabela.  They were blessed with six children: Hary Jun, 26 years old, Micheal, 24 years old, and Jomar, 23 years, were all college undergraduates; Roman – 18 years old, is currently in his second year of college; Roland – 13 years old, high school student; and Rio – 6 years old, already in grade one.  According to Rosalinda, the village where they live is peaceful and businesses are progressing since it is near to the public market of Ilagan, Isabela. 

Rosalinda has been helping her husband manage their small electronic shop in their village for almost 12 years. She wanted to make a difference in the coming days thus Rosalinda wanted to request a loan amounting to PHP7,000 that she can use as business capital.  She intends to use the loan to assist her husband in purchasing additional equipment or materials needed in their electronic shop and for the maintenance of their passenger jeep.  She said that their family business is really of great help in sustaining their needs and allowances of her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase of electronic parts

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta A. is a 58 year old mother of one child. Her son is called Ebo and he has successfully gained admission to the polytechnic. She lives, along with her husband, and works at Wasa Simpa in the western region of Ghana. Her husband is a crops farmer in the village. Atta is very hard working and resourceful for her family. She trades in charcoal and the sale of bathroom slippers in her neighborhood market. Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes.

Atta has been in business for the past ten years. She obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Wasa Simpa and treks to the big cities where she purchases her slippers. She then retails them to her customers. She wants to use this loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal and bathroom slippers to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan would enable her to increase her savings to pay her child's educational fees.

Atta belongs to a village bank called Cynthia. She also hopes to receive GH¢400 to make business progress by restocking her inventory.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of charcoal and bathroom slippers.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence D. is 47 years old. She is married with seven children, four males and three females. All are in senior high, junior high or basic schools. Her husband is a retired educatior while she is a food vendor. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Mampong, in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Florence prepares and sells Fante Kenkey, a local dish. ‘Fante’ is a tribe in Ghana. The food is so named because it probably originated from the Fante land. It is produced from corn dough. Florence buys bags of maize from farmers in the nearby villages and sells Kenkey in the local market square. She distributes mostly to retailers. She has been in this business for over 20 years.

She wants a loan to procure maize in bulk to be able to supply more customers. Florence also sells palm oil and provision besides the Kenkey business. Florence hopes to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: Buy maize in bulk.

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32 years old Zainabu G. from Mwanza. She is married with a one year old child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Zainabu has been running a beauty salon business since 2008.  This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, to make to look like your own. Zainabu works at the business for 8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Zainabu currently earns about 130USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase dryers and to renovate her building. In the future, she plans to open another business. Zainabu thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA!
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase dryers and to renovate her building

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia es socia del Banco Comunal Retoño.
Eugenia es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 3 hijos, Eugenia vende hoja de coca de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Nery García, sus productos los adquiere en la selva ayacuchana a donde viaja semanalmente.
Eugenia necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de hoja de coca.
Eugenia sueña con comprar una casa y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Eugenia is a member of the Banco Comunal Retoño. She has a live-in partner, is 39 years old, and has three children. Eugenia sells coca leaves as an ambulatory vendor in the Nery Garcia market. She gets her products from the Ayacuchana forest which she travels to every week. Eugenia needs a loan of 1500 soles (Peruvian currency) which will be used to purchase more coca leaves. She dreams of buying her own house and improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Coca leaves

loans.name: Mary

texts.es:
La Sra. Mary L., radica en la localidad D. la Guardia, a 20km. D. la cuidad D. Santa Cruz, en el barrio 3 D. mayo. Su esposo el Sr. Seferino Melgar se dedica a la actividad D. la agricultura en la localidad D. Sombrerito distante a 15 km. D. la Guardia, en la que tiene: plátanos, naranja , mandarina, lima, palta y otros.
Estos productos son comercializados por su esposa la Sra. Mary, en la cuidad D. Santa Cruz zona la Ramada.
Esta Sra. Se encuentra en su primer préstamo, en nuestra institución la cual se siente muy agradecida por brindarle el apoyo para que pueda seguir trabajando a pesar D. su avanzada edad. Lo cual le hace sentir ganas D. seguir aportando su granito D. arena para el desarrollo D. la comunidad.
texts.en:
Mary L. lives in the Guardia area, 20km from the city of Santa Cruz, in the 3 D. Mayo neighborhood. Her husband, Seferino Melgar is involved in agriculture in the Sombrerito area, which is 15km from Guardia. He has bananas, oranges, tangerines, limes, avocados, and other fruits and vegetables. Mary sells these products in the Ramada area of Santa Cruz.

This is Mary's first loan with this institution, and she is very grateful for the support, with which she will be able to continue working despite her age. She would like to continue contributing in a small way to the development of the community.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seasonal fruits

loans.name: Deeba Sadaqat Muhammad Latif Group

texts.en:
Deeba sadaqat baji is married to M. L. and they live in a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the back 10 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. Deeba baji operates a decorative embroidery business. She prepares embroidered dresses, on order, which she collect from the cloth shops. She completes a dress in 15 days and earns a good income. Her husband works in a factory on monthly wage. Deeba baji is applying for a loan to buy material (colored thread, cloth and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business.

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Zareena baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food selling business. Maqbool begum baji wants a loan to buy tools for her motor repair workshop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for decorative embroidery business.

loans.name: Afua

texts.en: Afua is 49 years old. She is divorced and a mother with six children. Three are currently in school and the other three children are working. She lives in the family house at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and serves food like beverages, rice and stew. She says demand for food is on the higher side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for six years now in taking care of the family. She wants to use the loan to buy meat and rice to increase her efficiency and to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to support her children's educational needs. She belongs to the village bank called ‘God’s Time is the Best’ and she would be grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy more rice and meat

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.en:
A. Mehriniso is 33 years old. She is married and has a little daughter. Mehriniso sells toys for children. She rents a store for selling, which is located in one of the local markets. Mehriniso has been running her own small business for seven years. Having only a couple competitors in the market, she is doing well with her business. Mehriniso always dreamed of owning her own small store and not having to depend on anyone else. She believes that someday her dream will come true and she will open her own store. Today she is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni for purchasing new toys to increase her range of goods. Mehriniso thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to be accurate with the loan payment. Let’s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dream become reality.  
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more toys to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Thol Korn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank group which consists of seventeen members is located in Ta Nu village in Kandal province, and they plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Thol K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is employed in a garment factory. She is also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

Mrs. Thol K. is 31 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.

Note: Mr. Sen S. did not come to take the loan but his wife did, so she is present in the picture instead.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to raise

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Since Salvacion and her husband Rolly got married, they have been raising pigs for their hog business. They started with one piglet that they raised and sold. This is their source of income to support the basic needs of their four children and their education. However, the hog business alone cannot finance the family's financial needs, therefore Salvacion also sells fish. Even with all of her hard work and perseverance, the business wasn't stable because of insufficient business capital. In 2003, Salvacion joined Ahon Sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI). She took out a loan from the institution to finance her business. As a result of the loans she received, her business has grown and she has been able to send all of her children to school. Three are high school graduates and her 8 year old youngest child is in elementary school. 

Out of the profits her business had generated, Salvacion was able to buy a motorcycle. Her desire for taking out a larger loan from ASHI is to increase her hog business and her profits to be able to buy a sidecar to attach to her motorcycle for a tricycle for hire business in the future.

Tricycle is one of the most common means of transportation all over the province. With this business, Salvacion could provide a daily income for her family's needs. She also hoped that out of her business profits her two children who are still in school will graduate from college.

loans.use: To support her hog business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock to expand his store's offerings

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme vend dans le grand marché de hédzranawoé à Lomé des vêtements de friperie plus précisément des pantalons deen et des T-shirts. Il a débuté ce commerce depuis 2000 grâce à l’aide d’un ami. Actuellement il maîtrise bien ce secteur  et réalise de bonnes affaires. Il s’approvisionne au Grand Marché de Lomé. Des clients viennent faires des commandes chez lui ; il vend aussi en gros à des revendeuses ambulantes de ces vêtements de friperie. Il a loué dans le marché un hangar sous lequel il vend ses vêtements. Il a besoin en ce moment de lancer une nouvelle commande ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter une bal de pantalons Jean et une bal de T-shirts. Il est célibataire et sans enfant. Il compte sur sa longue expérience pour vite rembourser ce prêt.

loans.use: Achat des bals de pantalons et de T-shirts

loans.name: Dorine

texts.en:
Dorine S., who runs a hair salon (Plaits style), is requesting a loan to purchase weaving materials of hair to sell. Dorine is 35 years old and married to a health worker. They have two children who go to school. With the profits from her loan, she hopes to employ some experts in her saloon shop.

----------------------- BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase weaving materials for her salon shop.

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita M. is from the village of Upper Puntod. She is 67 years old. Benita is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Benita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Benita has been engaged in her business for over 50 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Benita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benita successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Benita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Benita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Soumaya

texts.en:
Soumaya is a 55-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, capital city of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Soumaya has owned a grocery store for three and a half years. She sells canned food, candies, etc. Soumaya requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is her second cycle loan and she has always paid on time. 

Soumaya is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had to face some financial issues. Soumaya decided on doing her business because of her networking in her region. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mr. Pov C., age 41, and his wife, Mrs. Sophal Oeun, age 29, live along National Road Number Six about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1999 and have two children, who are in school. 

Pov has been a construction worker for 2 years. He works in his village. His wife has been selling fish for one year.  Their house is too small for their family. That is why Pov is applying for his first loan of $500 to renovate his house.

loans.use: To renovate the house where he lives.

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai Y., 53, and her husband Mr. Sophal Nou, 55, were married in 1976. They have seven children: three sons and four daughters. Five of the children have found full-time employment and the other two are in school. They live on an island in the Mekong River, approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia. 

Mrs. Lai Y. has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. Her husband has been a farmer for more than seven years. He grows ginger and papaya on his farm behind their house. Lai has taken one Kiva loan previously. She is now requesting another loan of $1,000 to help her husband’s farming business to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To help her husband’s farming business to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth de 29 años es una mujer muy alegre y luchadora, vive en su propia casa y lo que más anhela es mejorar su calidad de vida. Es por ello que Elizabeth se dedica diariamente a la confección de tejidos artesanales en su pequeño taller, donde trabaja sin parar para cubrir la cantidad de prendas que le han solicitado.
Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es tejer y lo hace con mucha habilidad, es así que ya lleva 9 años realizando esta actividad, pese a que se queda todo el día en su taller hasta cumplir con sus pedidos, pero lo hace con mucho empeño ya que desea en un futuro tener una tienda de tejidos, donde pueda vender sus prendas con mayor comodidad. 

Este es su sexto préstamo con MFP, por tanto promete pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente, para no perjudicar a sus compañeras de su banco comunal, ya que se le considera como una persona muy responsable y estimada. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más lana para elaborar nuevas prendas artesanales.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is 29 years old and is a cheerful and hardworking woman. She lives in her own home and what she longs for most is improving her standard of living. That is why she dedicates herself daily to the production of artisan weavings in her own workshop. Here she works nonstop to cover the quantity of pieces that have been requested from her in Desaguadero city (Puno Province, the border between Perú and Bolivia), since it is there that she sell her garments. What she likes most about her work is weaving, which she has done for 9 years and with great skill, even though she must remain all day in her shop until she fulfills her orders. She does this with great dedication since her wish is to have a shop where she can easily sell her garments. This is her sixth loan with MFP and promises to make timely payments so as not to jeopardize her communal bank colleagues since they consider her a responsible and esteemed person. With the thousand soles (Peruvian Soles) loan she will buy the wool required to produce more artisan garments.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more wool to make artisan weavings

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha es socia del Banco Comunal Tulipanes.
Martha es casada, tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, Martha vende repuestos en un local alquilado, actividad que realiza todos los días, además en el mismo lugar se encuentra el taller mecánico de su esposo. También vende cosméticos por catálogos.
Martha necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de accesorios de carros y lateria.
Los sueños de Martha son tener sucursales, vender mas variedad de repuestos y que su hija ingrese a la universidad.
texts.en:
Martha is a member of the Tulipanes ("Tulips") communal bank. Martha is 38 years old and married with 3 children. Martha works every day selling spare parts in rented business space. The same location also includes the mechanic's workshop operated by her husband. Martha also sells cosmetics out of catalogs. Martha needs a loan of 3000 Peruvian soles, which she will invest in purchasing car accessories and metal parts. Martha's dreams are to have a chain of shops, sell a broader variety of spare parts, and see her daughter enter the university.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing car accessories and metal parts

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira D. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is fifty-seven years old. Elvira is widowed and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Elvira owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP that she will use to invest in expanding her business. This will be Elvira's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nueva Union 5,6 Group

texts.en:
Alejandra is the coordinator of her group La Union (The Union), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Samana, a lush but rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their three children.

Alejandra is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and is excited for the opportunity to grow her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling sandals by the beach by purchasing different varieties of sandals to sell. She will use the profits to invest in her home by purchasing food and silverware, she would also like a TV. She will also invest in ehr children by purchasing school supplies. Her long term dream is to have her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Sandals to sell

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Mrs. D., 45, is married and the good mother of two kids, both of whom are single and working in the garment factory. She currently stays at home to prepare clothing that she gets from the factory for a profit. As another source of income, which is the main part that supports the family, her husband is a vehicle repairman. He has been providing his service for a long time, but he requires more tools. Therefore, D. is applying for a loan to buy mending accessories which her husband will use to perform his service.

loans.use: To buy mending accessories

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Cheikh T. est une femme de 67 ans, elle est veuve et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DAROU-KOUDOSS depuis 2ans et demi et a eu 5 expériences avec le crédit. Avec son nouveau prêt elle va développer un petit commerce de pâte d'arachide, de poivre, d'ail, de sel etc. Son objectif est de satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants et de leur assurer un avenir meilleur par la prise en charge de leur scolarité.
texts.en:
Cheikh T. is a 67 years old woman. She is a widow and a mother providing for five children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" Darou-Koudoss for two and half years. She has had five experiences with loans. With her new loan she will develop a small retail business of peanut butter, pepper, garlic, salt, etc. Her goal is to meet the needs of her children and to ensure them a better future by providing for their schooling fees.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To promote her small retail business

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila is a hardworking lady who has been offering her services as a seamstress in her community for the last four years. She runs her business in order to improve her family's standard of living. She sews designer and non-designer clothes very easily.
Jamila's husband is M. A., and they both want to give their children a good lifestyle. This purpose motivates them to overcome their problems. M. A. sells quilts and bedsheets to generate income. Once a month, he travels to various places to purchase these items for resale. Jamila is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s business by buying quilts and bedsheets in bulk.

loans.use: To buy quilts and bedsheets for resale

loans.name: Ines

texts.es:
No. de Socio: 31569 	No. de Foto: 211

Inés G. S. tiene 38 años, es casada, y  tiene seis hijos.  Vive en el cantón de San Miguel en la provincia de Bolívar.

La socia es miembro de la ventanilla rural La Palmera es un recinto que se encuentra a una hora y media  del Cantón San Miguel.  Son 16 socios en total, es una comunidad Agrícola y pocos a la Ganadera. 
Inés trabaja en la agricultura y en los que aceres domésticos,  para incrementar la economía de la familia.  Los cultivos que más sobresalen son el maíz, morocho, choclo, fréjol, habas.  Vende los productos en el mercado de San Miguel en la Feria de los Jueves.

En los momentos que no hay trabajo le gusta pasar con los hijos y compartir las fiestas con los vecinos como es la navidad y el carnaval.

La socia solicita el crédito para comprar insumos para el trabajo del campo y sobre todo para fertilizantes y abonos.  Su meta es tener una buena actividad económica para la familia y para la compra de un carro para el trabajo.  Los desafíos que enfrenta son los problemas climáticos, las enfermedades que afectan a los cultivos y la falta de dinero para la compra de insumos.
texts.en:
Inés G. S. is 38 years old, is married and has six children. She lives near San Miguel in the province of Bolívar.

The member is a part of La Palmera communal bank, it is in a rural area, and it is an hour and a half from Cantón San Miguel. There are 16 members in total, it is an agricultural community and a few are cattle-dealers.

Inés works in agriculture and in her home to improve her families’ financial state. The crops that stand out in production are corn, morocho (dry cracked corn used in beverages and food), choclo (green ear of corn), beans, and habas (broad beans). She sells her products in the San Miguel market in Thursday’s fair.

When there is no work, she likes to spend time with her children and to share parties with her neighbors like Christmas and carnival.

Inés needs the loan to buy merchandize for her work in the field and for fertilizer and manure. Her goal is to have a good economic activity for the family and to buy a car for work. The challenges that she faces are due to climate, the diseases that hurt her crops and the lack of money to buy goods for her crops.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and supplies for production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Nakinyuguzi 2 Birabwa Allen Group

texts.en: Allen B. is a hardworking business lady of twenty-five years of age. She is a married with two children in school. Allen is a tailor and has been offering tailoring services for over three years. She will the loan to purchase cloth and thread for her business. Allen is an ambitious businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children and improve upon their welfare.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and thread for her business.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla I. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 45 years old, married, and has an 18-year-old child. To make a living, Perla owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises pigs for fattening and sale.
In 2008, Perla joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Perla is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and feed for the pigs. This loan will be her fifth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About CEVI
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and pig feed

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel es una madre de familia de 51 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus dos hijos en el distrito de Cura Mori, un distrito perteneciente a la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre. Se encuentra ubicado a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Al igual que la mayoría de mujeres de la zona se dedica desde hace veinte años a la preparación y venta de chicha y a la crianza y venta de animales. La chicha es una bebida típica del país elaborada a base de harina de maíz. Se consume desde tiempos ancestrales, actualmente es consumida por los habitantes de zonas rurales en celebraciones y antes de empezar sus faenas, ya que creen que les da fuerza y vigor. 

Isabel prepara la chicha en su vivienda dos veces por semana y la ofrece en venta a sus vecinos. Adicionalmente cría animales de corral en su vivienda para venderlos a los negociantes que visitan la zona con regularidad.

Isabel desea adquirir insumos para seguir preparando chicha y alimento balanceado para mejorar la calidad de sus animales y obtener mayores ganancias al momento de venderlos. Para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Isabel is a 51 year old mother who lives with her husband and two children in the district of Cura Mori. This district is part of the province and region of Piura, and is located three hours away from the city of Chiclayo.

Like most of the women in the area, Isabel has been preparing and selling “chicha” for twenty years. She also raises and sells animals. Chicha is a traditional Peruvian beverage made of corn and is consumed during ancestral ceremonies. Many people who live in rural areas drink it during parties and before starting their chores since they believe it provides strength and energy.

Isabel prepares chicha twice a week in her home and sells it to her neighbors. She also raises farm animals at home to sell to the merchants who regularly pass through the area. Isabel wants to acquire supplies so that she can continue producing chicha. In addition, she wishes to purchase balanced feed to improve the quality of her animals and generate better earnings when she sells them. In order to accomplish this goal, she is requesting her first loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 500 PEN.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for making "chicha" & feed for her animals

loans.name: Berta

texts.es:
Berta es socia del Banco Comunal Santa Rita.
Berta es casada y tiene 2 hijas que ya son independientes, Berta tiene un taller de confección en su casa en donde confecciona ropa típica, actividad que realiza junto a su esposo, sus productos los vende en el mercado, además Berta vende comida típica los días domingos en su casa.
Berta solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas.
Los sueños de Berta son comprar un carro para que realice transporte publico y seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Berta is a member of the communal bank Santa Rita. Berta is married and has two children who are already independent. Berta has a sewing studio in her house where she makes traditional clothing, an activity that she does with her husband. They sell their products in the market, also Berta sells typical foods on Sundays in her house. Berta is seeking a loan of 1000 Soles that she will invest in the purchase of fabrics. Berta's dreams are to buy a car to provide transportation and to continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Nourn P., 39, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations.

P. and her husband are vegetable sellers, earning an income of US $6 per day. P. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Jesus

texts.es:
El señor Jesús  es viudo; vive con sus hijos de 27, 25, 6 y 4 años  en  casa propia en la zona de Pasankeri sur de esta ciudad de La Paz. El señor Jesús es comerciante se dedica a la compra y venta de llamas es así como obtiene sus ingresos para el hogar.

El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de un muro posterior de su domicilio mejorando así su calidad de vida. Es su tercer crédito y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Sr. Jesús is a widower. He lives with his children (ages 27, 25, 6, and 4) in his own home in the district of Pasankeri, which is in the southern part of the city of La Paz. Sr. Jesús is a merchant who buys and sells llamas to generate household income. The loan he is requesting will be used to build a wall behind his home, which will improve his quality of life. This is his third loan and the socioeconomic analysis indicates he has a favorable rating, thereby making him eligible to access this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a wall behind his house to provide better security

loans.name: Teresa Albertina

texts.es:
Teresa de 49 años, ella vende dulces en la ventana de su casa que readecuo para tener mas ingresos, vive en la Perimetral de Guayaquil una zona rodeada del estero salado de Guayaquil. 

Ella hacia tortas y bocaditos conociendo a los hijos de sus clientas, comenzó hablándole a los niños de Dios poco a poco fueron yendo a su casa y ella les ofrecía dulces, ahora los niños les compran cada vez que van. Desde ese tiempo readecuo su casa y ubico a lado de su ventana una pequeña dulcería.

Ella esta variando la mercadería que vende por eso quiere el préstamo para comprar  bandejas, vasos y platos. En el futuro quiere tener mejor surtidos sus dulces y ay tener un local. También seguir hablándole de Dios a los niños del sector.
texts.en:
Teresa is 49 years old. She sells sweets from a window in her house, which she adapted to get more income. She lives in on the Perimetral Highway in Guayaquil in an area surrounded by the salt marsh. She makes cakes and snacks. She met her customers’ children, and she started to talk to the children about God. Little by little they went to her house, and she offered them sweets. Now the children buy each time they go there. She adapted her house and located a small business selling sweets next to her window. She is varying the merchandise that she sells. That is why she wants the loan to buy trays, glasses, and plates. In the future she wants to have a better stock of sweets and to have a shop. She will also continue to talk about God to the children in the sector.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Trays, gasses, and plates

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es: El señor Julio Cesar E. de 66 años se ha dedicado desde su juventud a la elaboración de zapatos y es esta materia la que le ha servido para salir adelante y mantener a su familia, a pesar de su avanzada edad, nos cuenta que aún tiene las fortalezas para preparar un encargo semanal o quincenal de zapatos y entregarlos en los departamentos del norte del país que es donde principalmente comercializa sus productos.
texts.en:
Julio Cesar E., 66, has worked since he was young making shoes. This work has allowed him to get ahead and support his family. In spite of his advanced age, he tells us that he still has the strength to fill his weekly or bi-weekly orders for shoes and deliver them in departments (administrative regions) in the northern part of the country, which is where he sells most of his products.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy materials to make shoes

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Susan has a business of tailoring, which she has had for 2 years.  She also rears chickens.  

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more materials (cloth).  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Susan hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food.  

In the future, Susan hopes to spend more on her business and own a car and a house. Susan is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future since she can repay the money on time because the interest rent is low.

loans.use: to buy more materials such as cloth

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria L. is married to Manolito L., Jr., who is fifty years old and works as an operator to earn his living. They have six children who range in age from 14 to 28 years old. Two of their children have their own families, one is employed, two are looking for jobs and the youngest is currently going to school. The family lives in the barangay of Talavera, a part of Toledo City on Cebu island. Maria runs two businesses: a sari-sari (general) store and a ready-to-wear clothing shop.

Maria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 14,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, thus lifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her sixth loan cycle, she is borrowing 16,000 PHP which she intends to use to buy more ready-to-wear clothes to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future and help her youngest finish school. Maria L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy more ready-to-wear clothes to sell

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in Punjab and is famous for its agriculture industry in Pakistan. She is 26 years old and lives there in a two-room brick house with her family. She moved here after her marriage a few years ago. 

She is a housewife and prefers to stay at home to do her household responsibilities. She is married to A. J. who works in the fields. He owns a small piece of land on which he grows wheat and other seasonal crops. He also operates a business selling fertilizer & seeds.
  
Irshad has given birth to three daughters and a son. None of them is of school-going age and Irshad wants to provide them a quality education once they become of school-going age. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy seeds & fertilizer to sell to his customers.  She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will prove a profitable experience for her family. 

Note: “In this photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Irshad”.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds for reselling

loans.name: Machimbo Group

texts.en:
Asha K. is in her early 30s and is a single mother taking care of two children. Asha runs a small food stall where she sells basic groceries and charcoal. The stall is open between 6 am and 6 pm and earns Asha a low monthly profit. 


This will be Asha's fifth loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. Asha used her previous loans to increase her stock of goods and to improve her stall. These loans were all successfully repaid. With this loan, Asha aims to increase her business by increasing her stock of charcoal and improve the condition of the stall.

Asha will share this loan with her loan group Machimbo, which totals 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Asha can be seen third from left in the first row.

loans.use: To Increase the stock of charcoal and improve the stall.

loans.name: Bebelyn

texts.en:
Bebelyn R. is from the village of Bagakay, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Bebelyn is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Bebelyn owns and operates a grocery store. Bebelyn has been engaged in her business for more than 18 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Bebelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Bebelyn has successfully repaid a loan of 8000 PHP. She is now requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional grocery stocks. This will be the third loan taken by Bebelyn from PMPC.
